instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023A: What is 820-3023A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi:


I will appreciate any help in diagnosing missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> due to which the system is unable to detect embedded LCD panel.
On checking I find that <SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> (input to <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>) is also low.

System boots and external display port is working.

Please Guide...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> must appears in the first few seconds, usually when board chimes.
Then <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high.
If not, PCH doesn't detect LCD and disables <SIGNAL>3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>.
If OK, then voltage is maintained.

Did you try known good compatible LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Tried with known good panel and rechecked the connection pins. No <SIGNAL>3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL> still...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Put voltmeter on that line, start the board and wait.
That voltage MUST appear even without LCD connected; but will disappear rapidly I suppose, in such case.
Check if at least <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> enable trys to appear...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi!
Yes, the supply does come after 5 seconds for a couple and then disappears.

On investigating further I found the case of a bad pad under L9004 leading to the system not registering the EDP. Replacing the Inductor and making good the connection restored the EDP display as well as backlight.

Thanks again for your help !
